history.content:
You should have looked for more options earlier. There were plenty of spaces available if you actually understand how enrollment works. I feel like most people cannot get into an upper div cs class because 

1) they do not understand how enrollment works and do not know which resources are most helpful. Do you know you can use classes.berkeley.edu to see the most accurate status of a class/section? and not berkeley time or whatever. Make sure you know how reserve rules work / when they are removed / when do new sections open / TA hirings, 70% rule / how does course conflict prevent people from getting into the class / 999 sections vs regular sections etc.

2) they don't have enough time to keep checking for available spaces/updates in classes.

3) they have course conflicts for the newly opened sections if they did not have priority or have late enrollment time

I know that enrollment times are important but as for myself, I got into 3 upper div cs classes 188, 170, 186 using 1 in phase 2 and 2 in adjustments and fyi I only declared a few days ago. 

I think most classes are already expanded/full, you might get into some of them if some people drop. Just visit EECS101 piazza regularly, or read the upper div enrollment rules carefully and you will have better luck next time :/

---------

I think you have a good chance of getting in for 161. I think you have a decent chance of getting into 170 but it might be a little tougher. If I remember correctly, the 10% rule says that roughly 10% of the class will drop by the deadline. This means roughly 60 people will drop 170 and 55 people will drop 161.

You should have looked for more options earlier. There were plenty of spaces available if you actually understand how enrollment works. I feel like most people cannot get into an upper div cs class because 

1) they do not understand how enrollment works and do not know which resources are most helpful. Do you know you can use classes.berkeley.edu to see the most accurate status of a class/section? and not berkeley time or whatever. Make sure you know how reserve rules work / when they are removed / when do new sections open / TA hirings, 70% rule / how does course conflict prevent people from getting into the class / 999 sections vs regular sections etc.

2) they don't have enough time to keep checking for available spaces/updates in classes.

3) they have course conflicts for the newly opened sections if they did not have priority or have late enrollment time

I know that enrollment times are important but as for myself, I got into 3 upper div cs classes 188, 170, 186 using 1 in phase 2 and 2 in adjustments and fyi I only declared a few days ago. 

I think most classes are already expanded/full, you might get into some of them if some people drop. Just visit EECS101 piazza regularly, or read the upper div enrollment rules carefully and you will have better luck next time :/

children.subject: It definitely depends on the course and how long you're willing to stick with it. I took 188 last spring and managed to get in as over 200 on the waitlist (at the start of adjustment, for a 500-ish person class) because over 100 dropped after the first project. Good luck!

history.content:
My Phase 1 was really late, and I signed up for like 4 upper divs but I am waitlisted for all of them. My biggest hopes are that I am 20th for CS161 and 60th for CS170. Are those classes expanding, or is it possible that I can get in? I know an instructor said earlier that 170 might be expanded after picking TA's, has that expansion happened yet? Because otherwise I have no idea what I am going to do since I literally cannot sign up for any CS courses and I've taken most of my breadths already.

Also, I just declared CS, and in the email they said I would be moved up based on priority but I've only really gone up like 5 places since then.
history.subject: Waitlisted for Everything.
